The following is one stanza of canto Ⅵ of the Kumāra-saṃbhava (“the birth of Kumāra”) by the great Sanskrit poet Kālidāsa: <br>
 <br>
    पशुपतिरपि तान्यहानि कृच्छ्राद् <br>
    अगमयदद्रिसुतासमागमोत्कः । <br>
    कमपरमवशं न विप्रकुर्युर् <br>
    विभुमपि तं यदमी स्पृशन्ति भावाः ॥ <br>
 <br>
And here is the transcription of it: <br>
 <br>
    Paśupatirapi tānyahāni kṛcchrād <br>
    agamayadadrisutāsamāgamotkaḥ; <br>
    kamaparamavaśaṃ na viprakuryur <br>
    vibhumapi taṃ yadamī spṛśanti bhāvāḥ? <br>
 <br>
A rough translation might be: <br>
 <br>
    And Paśupati passed those days with hardship, / eager for union with the daughter of the mountain. / Which other powerless [creature] would they not torment, / such emotions, when they affect even the powerful [Śiva]?
